newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crude - Tapis traded at deep discount.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude - Tapis traded at deep discount.

text.p: Asian crude prices firmed slightly on Monday on strength in the west late last week, traders said.
August Tapis swap was bid at $19.05 per barrel late Monday, up 20 cents from Friday, unperturbed by a shock physical deal.
News a western trader had sold an August Tapis cargo to a U.S. major at APPI -40 stunned the market, causing traders to reassess their outlook for the light crude market.
The same seller had earlier bought the Tapis from a producer at APPI +2, leading some traders to question if there was more to the deal than was known so far.
Traders had expected Tapis premiums against APPI to stabilise because APPI outright quotes have been falling.
The premium of 2 cents was the lowest seen in over a year.
But some refiners said that with gasoil prices still under $20.00, it was natural that Tapis levels had to fall further to provide respite to refining margins.
"APPI Tapis has been falling mainly with Brent prices, not with gasoil. Refiners would be operating at negative margins if they were to run Tapis," said a trader with a major oil company.
Heavy crudes remained supported, with 150,000 barrels of August Minas heard sold by an equity holder to Japan at ICP +85.
The Middle East crude market was thin, with August trading almost finished.
Only a few partial cargoes of Oman and Abu Dhabi crudes are available.
But traders said that at least three cargoes of August Masila were still on offer, with limited interest seen, following a wider Brent/Dubai spread.
A western trader sold September Oman to a South Korean refiner, in exchange for a September Dubai, at a differential of 23 cents.
